byline.contributor: Peter Baker reported from Washington, and Michael D. Shear from New York. Reporting from Washington was contributed by Nicholas Fandos, Laurie Goodstein, Fernanda Santos, Jada Smith and Jim Yardley.
byline.original: By PETER BAKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

abstract: Pope Francis delivers his first message in United States during visit to White House, focusing on polarizing issues of poverty, climate change and immigration; Francis's appearance with Pres Obama highlights their common goals of addressing global warming and helping the disenfranchised, putting forth possibility of secular-theological front in addressing world's ills.
lead_paragraph: Francis, who met with President Obama and Catholic bishops, waded into two of America’s most charged debates, on immigration and the environment.

headline.main: Pope Francis, in Washington, Addresses Poverty and Climate
headline.print_headline: Pope’s First U.S. Message Is Pastoral and Political

snippet: Francis, who met with President Obama and Catholic bishops, waded into two of America’s most charged debates, on immigration and the environment.
